Graphical abstract Highlights This study investigates the effect of the cobalt precursor (nitrate and acetate) on the catalytic performance in the Fischer-Tropsch synthesis of catalysts supported on stabilized CoAl2O4/Al2O3 pellets. The catalysts are prepared via multi-steps of impregnation of the support with aqueous solutions of cobalt nitrate or acetate followed by calcination in air. The dispersion of the Co3O4 particles obtained via exothermic decomposition of acetate increases if each impregnation is followed by calcination. In fact, halving the calcinations leads to Co3O4 particles even bigger than those formed from cobalt-nitrate. A worsening of the catalytic performances is observed when the Co-acetate catalysts are tested in the FTS. Such a result is explained on the basis of Co0 particles size effect. Pt improves the catalysts reducibility regardless of the Co-precursor. The metallic surface area of the Pt-promoted Co-nitrate catalyst is higher than that of the corresponding Co-acetate catalyst, thus resulting in improved catalytic performances. Keywords Cobalt precursor Cobalt acetate Pt-promotion Stabilized alumina Fischer-Tropsch • The catalysts are prepared via multi-steps of impregnation using Co-acetate and Co-nitrate as Co-precursors. • The number of calcinations strongly affects the Co3O4 dispersion in the Co-acetate catalysts. • Too much small Co particles are obtained when each Co-acetate impregnation is followed by treatment in air. • Pt improves the catalysts reducibility regardless of the type of the starting Co-precursor. • The performances of the catalysts in the FTS are explained with a particles size effect. 1 Introduction The Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS) aims at producing high-quality synthetic fuels and valuable chemicals from carbon sources different from oil [1,2]. Cobalt-based catalysts are conventionally used for the low temperature Fischer-Tropsch (LTFT) synthesis carried out at high pressure (P = 20-30 bar) and low temperature (T ≤ 240 °C). LTFT aims at producing high molecular weight paraffinic waxes, as a major product, which are subsequently hydrocracked to lubricants and diesel fuels [3]. Cobalt-based catalysts are usually prepared via impregnation of an oxide support, such as Al2O3, SiO2 or TiO2, with an aqueous solution containing the Co-precursor. Cobalt nitrate and cobalt acetate are the precursors most commonly used in the scientific literature [4]. Impregnation is then followed by drying and eventually calcination to form Co3O4 particles from the Co-nitrate or the Co-acetate species. The LTFT proceeds on the Co° surface sites formed after the catalyst activation step, usually consisting in a H2-reduction at 350-450 °C [4]. The number of active sites depends on the cobalt loading, usually kept around 20-30 wt.%, on the reduction degree of the catalyst, and on the size of the Co° particles [4,5]. These parameters are closely interconnected, since: (i) the higher is the cobalt loading, the lower is the dispersion of Co3O4 crystallites (i.e. Co3O4 crystallites size); (ii) the effectiveness of the reduction process strictly depends on the dimension of the starting Co3O4 particles, with smaller supported Co3O4 crystallites being more difficult to reduce [4,5]. At the same time, the LTFT shows structure sensitivity dependence on the Co° crystallite size being the turnover frequency (TOF) decreasing with decreased crystallite size below 8 nm [6–9]. Accordingly, the optimal Co-based catalyst for the LTFT is characterized by crystallites large enough to have the maximum TOF. Notably, it has to be considered that even the product distribution is affected by the catalyst dispersion [6–9]. In fact, it has been proposed that H2 dissociation on small Co° clusters is favored over that of CO, thus leading to higher H/C ratios at the catalytic surface on highly dispersed catalysts [10]. This results in a lower chain growth probability, which causes the shift of the product distribution towards undesired lower molecular weight hydrocarbons, and in a higher probability of chain termination via hydrogenation, which favors short chain paraffins over olefins [10]. The size of the Co0 crystallites also affects the operating times of the catalyst in the FT reaction. Indeed, small Co0 particles are more prone to re-oxidation by water and sintering into big clusters, especially under realistic FTS conditions (i.e. high CO conversion levels≈ high water partial pressures), thus resulting in a worsening of the catalyst life time [11–12]. With the aim of improving the catalytic performances of LTFT catalysts, many studies were focused on the effect of the Co-precursor used for the impregnation [13–25]. In the case of SiO2 supported catalysts, it was shown that the precursor used for the Co-impregnation step has a strong effect on the final catalyst properties. In particular, it was found that Co3O4 crystallites obtained upon calcination of the Co-nitrate precursor are bigger in size (≥ 20 nm) than those obtained upon the decomposition of the Co-acetate precursor (≤ 8 nm) [13–23]. This was attributed to the high mobility of the nitrate precursor over the support during calcination due to the fact that its decomposition is very slow. The precursor decomposition rate is accelerated when acetate is used, thanks to the combustion of the organic components. This, in turn, prevents the mobility of the cobalt particles thus favoring the final cobalt dispersion [26]. However, as mentioned above, the small Co3O4 crystallites obtained using Co-acetate, were found to be barely reducible by H2-reduction, thus leading to a final number of Co0 active sites lower than that obtained using Co-nitrate [13–23]. Also, the TOF of the active sites obtained using Co-acetate was lower than the TOF of the active sites obtained using Co-nitrate [13–23]. Furthermore, the products distribution was shifted towards shorter saturated hydrocarbons with respect to that obtained with the catalyst obtained using Co-nitrate. As a result, lower catalytic performances were measured with the catalyst prepared using Co-acetate [13–23]. Aiming at the development of SiO2 supported catalysts with an optimal dispersion of the Co-acetate precursor (i.e. limiting the formation Co3O4 crystallites smaller than 8 nm) different strategies were considered [13,15,23]. These involved: (i) decreasing the calcination temperature from 400-500 °C, which are typical of the catalysts prepared with Co-nitrate, down to 170 °C [15]; (ii) using equimolar amount of Co-acetate and Co-nitrate aqueous solutions for the impregnation of the support [13]; (iii) performing the decomposition of the precursor in N2-atmosphere at 350 °C [23]. Among these strategies only the latter was successful, since the CO conversion of the resulting Co-acetate catalyst was almost doubled with respect to that measured over the corresponding Co-nitrate sample [23]. At variance, only few studies were focused on the effect of Co-acetate on γ-Al2O3 [23–25], a material which is also frequently employed as support due to its high thermal stability, high mechanical strength and high thermal conductivity. All these studies, however, reported a worsening of the catalytic performances when the γ-Al2O3 support was impregnated with Co-acetate instead of Co-nitrate. This was explained with the fact that γ-Al2O3 strongly interacts with cobalt particles, especially if smaller than 10 nm, leading to the formation of Co-alumina mixed compounds that are inactive in the FTS [23–25]. These species can be formed during the catalyst activation in H2 and under FT reaction conditions and they are strongly undesired since they are reducible only at harsh conditions (>800 °C in H2) [27–29]. The formation of cobalt aluminates can be prevented by surface modification of the support [30] or through the stabilization of γ-Al2O3 with chemical elements prior to the deposition of the active phase [4]. Concerning the latter, it implies the formation of a protective layer of metal oxides between γ-Al2O3 and the active Co phase [4]. In this regard, the presence of a protective layer of AlPO4 was found effective in preventing the formation of CoAl2O4 species during reaction [31]. Mg-aluminates [32], Zn-aluminates [33] and Co-aluminates [34] were also proposed as stabilizing additives. Among these spinels, CoAl2O4 was the most promising for the FTS [34], since both Mg and Zn negatively affected the catalyst activity and selectivity, with an increase of the water gas shift activity due to a likely chemical/site effect similar to that of alkalies reported in literature [32–33]. In this regard, we also recently confirmed the effectiveness of a CoAl2O4 stabilized Al2O3 support in preventing any possible interaction between Co centers and Al2O3 during the catalyst activation in H2 and under FTS conditions [5,35]. Preventing the formation of inactive CoAl2O4 species during reaction is crucial since enables to increase the operating times of the catalyst even at a laboratory scale. In this work, we want to provide further insights on the effect of the Co-precursor (Co-nitrate and Co-acetate) on the structural and catalytic properties of Co-based catalysts supported on γ-Al2O3 pellets stabilized with CoAl2O4 species. In this regard, the Co-acetate catalysts are prepared with two different approaches: (i) by following a procedure as similar as possible to that used for the Co-nitrate catalyst, which means keeping constant the number of thermal treatments used for the Co-nitrate sample and (ii) by doubling the number of thermal treatments with respect to the Co-nitrate sample. Furthermore, the presence of 0.1 wt.% of Pt in the formulation of those Co-nitrate and Co-acetate catalysts prepared with the same number of thermal treatments is investigated. In this respect, although Pt is widely used as promoter for catalysts prepared with Co-nitrate, to the best of our knowledge no results are available in the open literature on its effect on samples prepared from Co-acetate. 2 Experimental Section 2.1 Catalysts Preparation All the catalysts of this study are supported on γ-Al2O3 pellets (Sasol Puralox®, dpellet=300 μm) stabilized with CoAl2O4 species. The stabilization procedure is described in detail in [5]. Briefly, 5.7 wt.% of Co is impregnated onto the γ-Al2O3 pellets (incipient wetness impregnation, IWI) using an aqueous solution of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (Sigma Aldrich, 98 wt.%) and then, the obtained material is dried in static air at 120 °C for 1 h and calcined at 900 °C for 4 h (heating rate 1.5 °C/min) [5]. The stabilized support will be indicated in the following as Al2O3 (s) . For the preparation of the nitrate and acetate samples containing an additional 19 wt.% of active cobalt, the Al2O3 (s) support is impregnated (IWI) four times with an aqueous solution of Co(NO3)2∙6H2O (CoNit/Al2O3 (s) sample), or eight times with aqueous solution of Co(CH3COO)2∙4H2O (Sigma Aldrich, 99 wt.%) (CoAc/Al2O3 (s) and CoAc VIII/Al2O3 (s) catalysts), seeing that the solubility of the Co-acetate precursor is much lower than that of the Co-nitrate (0.38 vs. 1.038 g/ml). The CoNit/Al2O3 (s) and CoAc/Al2O3 (s) samples are calcined for the same number of times. Accordingly the Co-nitrate sample is dried in static air at 80 °C for 2 h (heating rate: 2 °C/min) and calcined in static air at 500 °C for 4 h (heating rate: 2 °C/min) after each impregnation step, while the Co-acetate catalyst every two impregnation steps. This means that both the samples are calcined four times. In contrast, CoAc VIII/Al2O3 (s) catalyst is calcined after each Co-impregnation step, which means that the sample is calcined eight times. Pt-promoted Co-nitrate (CoNit/Pt/Al2O3 (s) ) and Co-acetate (CoAc/Pt/Al2O3 (s) ) catalysts are prepared by following the reverse sequential deposition (RSD) procedure reported in [35]. Following this method, 0.1 wt.% of Pt is impregnated on the Al2O3 (s) support using an aqueous solution of 3.4 wt.% of Pt(NH3)2∙(NO2)2 in NH4OH (Sigma Aldrich, 99 wt.%). The obtained material is dried in static air at 120 °C for 2 h (heating rate: 2 °C/min) and then calcined at 500 °C for 4 h (heating rate: 2 °C/min), obtaining a sample named Pt/Al2O3 (s). Eventually, 19 wt.% of Co is impregnated on the Pt/Al2O3 (s) by adopting the same procedure used for the Pt-free CoNit/Al2O3 (s) and CoAc/Al2O3 (s) catalysts (i.e. by using the same number of thermal treatments for both Co-nitrate and Co-acetate). 2.2 Characterization of the samples 2.2.1 TG/DTA and O2-TPSR TG/DTA measurements are conducted using a STA7300 Thermal Analysis system in order to evaluate the phenomena occurring during the first calcination step, which is reasonably representative of all the following thermal steps. All the samples (CoNit/Al2O3 (s), CoNit/Pt/Al2O3 (s), CoAc/Al2O3 (s) and CoAc/Pt/Al2O3 (s)) are initially calcined after loading ≈4.8 wt.% of active Co, except the CoAc VIII/Al2O3 (s) sample that is calcined after loading ≈2.4 wt.% of Co. Notably, these amounts of Co do not include the amount of cobalt used for the support stabilization. The samples will be named respectively: 4.8CoNit, 4.8CoNit/Pt, 4.8CoAc, 4.8CoAc/Pt and 2.4CoAc, for the sake of clarity. To this scope, the samples are placed in the furnace and heated in a stream of synthetic air (110 Nl/h/gcat) from ambient temperature to 500 °C at a heating rate of 2 °C/min. Temperature programmed surface reaction analysis (O2-TPSR) in diluted oxygen (100 Nl/h/gcat, 2.06 vol.% O2 in He) are also carried out on the 4.8CoNit and 2.4CoAc samples in order to evaluate the species formed during the decomposition of the Co-precursors. To this end, the sample is heated from 50 to 500 °C at a heating rate of 8 °C/min. The gas products are analysed by using an on-line quadrupole mass-spectrometer (Pfeiffer Omnistar). The following mass-to-charge ratios (m/e) are detected: 18 (H2O), 28 (CO, N2), 30 (NO), 32 (O2), 44 (CO2) and 46 (NO2). 2.2.2 Adsorption isotherms and elemental composition The BET area (SBET) and the specific pore volume (Vp) of the samples are obtained from the N2 adsorption isotherms measured at −196 °C in a Micromeritics Tristar 3000 instrument. The BJH method is used to calculate the average pore size (dp) and the pore size distribution from the adsorption branch of the isotherm. Inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (Thermo Fischer, X series II ICP-MS) is used to quantify the Co and Pt loadings on the calcined catalysts. Notably, the Co loading obtained from ICP-MS involves the amount of cobalt used to stabilize the starting γ-Al2O3 pellets and the amount of active Co loaded during the impregnation steps of the active phase. 2.2.3 XRD A X-ray Bruker D8 Advanced diffractometer equipped with monochromatized Cu-Kα radiation (λ=1.5418 Å) is used to analyze the oxide state of the catalysts obtained after calcination. The average Co3O4 particle size is calculated using the half-width at half-height of the most intense peak (at 2θ = 37.06°, ≈1000 counts) of the diffraction pattern and the Scherrer equation. Notably, the diffractogram obtained after the subtraction of the diffraction pattern of the Al2O3 (s) from that of the catalyst is used, due to the fact that the diffraction peaks representing the cobalt aluminates (main peaks at 36.4 and 42.9°) species overlap with those of Co3O4. 2.2.4 H2-TPR A quartz microreactor loaded with 0.1 g of catalyst is used to perform H2-TPR analyses on a Micromeritics Thermoquest TPDRO1100 instrument equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The gas stream, composed by a mixture of 5% H2 diluted in Ar (36 Nl/h/gcat), is fed into the microreactor and then the system is heated from 40 to 1050 °C at a heating rate of 15 °C/min. The H2-TPR analyses are carried out over the calcined catalysts and after in-situ reduction of these samples at 400 °C for 17 h under a flow of pure H2 (5 Nl/h/gcat). H2 consumption in the reduced catalysts corresponds with the amount of cobalt oxide present on the catalysts after the treatment in H2 at 400 °C (eq. (3)): (3) x C o 0 % = m o l C o 0 r e d u c e d / m o l C o 0 t h 2.2.5 H2-chemisorption The active surface metal of the catalyst is measured by H2-chemisorption in the same microreactor and instrument used for H2-TPR experiments. The analysis is carried out by sending thirty pulses of H2 (264 μL/pulse) over 0.3 g of catalyst in-situ reduced in H2 at 400 °C for 17 h. The H2-chemisorbed uptake ( m o l H 2 c h e m i / g c a t ) is measured at 100 °C. Dispersion percentage (D, [%]) is calculated according to eq. (4), assuming a chemisorption stoichiometry of Co:H equal to 1. (4) D % = ( m o l H 2 c h e m i / g c a t ) ∙ 2 / ( m o l C o 0 r e d u c e d / g c a t ) where m o l H 2 c h e m i / g c a t is the total amount of H2 chemisorbed in the experiment and m o l C o 0 r e d u c e d / g c a t is the amount of metallic cobalt on the reduced catalysts. (5) [36]: (5) d C o c h e m i 0 n m = 96 / D [ % ] 2.3 Catalytic performance All the prepared catalysts are tested in the FTS using a fixed bed tubular reactor (1.1 cm ID) after dilution with α-Al2O3 pellets of the same granulometry, so as to grant isothermal conditions of the catalyst bed (catalyst: alumina = 1: 4 v/v). More details on the lab-scale FT plant can be found in [37] and references therein. Catalytic runs are performed at conditions relevant to industrial operations, such as T=210 °C, P=25 bar, H2/CO inlet molar ratio = 2.0, GHSV = 6.41 Nl/h/gcat, inerts (N2+ Ar) in the feed=24 vol.%. The catalyst is activated in-situ by flowing pure H2 (5.0 Nl/h/gcat) at 400 °C for 17 h with a heating rate of 2 °C/min. The unconverted reactants and the gaseous products are analyzed with an on-line gas chromatograph, while liquid products are measured by an off-line gas-chromatograph. More details on the product sampling and analysis procedures can be found elsewhere [37]. The CO conversion ( X C O % , eq. (6)) and the selectivity to the main FTS products ( S i % , eq. (7)) are calculated as follows: (6) X C O % = ( 1 - F C O o u t / F C O i n ) ∙ 100 (7) S i % = ( F i o u t ∙ n i / ∑ i N P ( F i o u t ∙ n i ) ) ∙ 100 F i o u t is the molar productivity of ith hydrocarbon species, n i is the carbon atom number of the ith species and NP is the number of the hydrocarbon products (paraffins C1–C49 and olefins C2–C17). The carbon balances is calculated as the ratio between the moles of C contained in the reaction products and the moles of CO converted. It always closes within ±5%. The intrinsic catalytic activity (turnover frequency, TOF) is also calculated as in eq. (8): (8) T O F [ s - 1 ] = r C O 0 2 ∙ m o l H 2 c h e m i where r C O 0 is the CO consumption rate [mol/s/gcat] estimated at the reactor inlet by using the rate expression (eq. (9)) proposed by Zennaro et al. [38]: (9) r C O = k T P C O - 0.24 P H 2 0.74 3 Results and Discussion 3.1 Catalysts Characterization 3.1.1 Decomposition of the Co-precursor on the dried catalysts The decomposition of the Co-nitrate precursor with and without Pt in the catalysts formulation (4.8CoNit and 4.8CoNit/Pt) are shown in Fig. 1 (a, d). In the case of the Pt-free catalyst (Fig. 1(a)), weight losses (≈21%) are seen in the 50–120 °C T-range and in the 120–300 °C T-range (≈11%) due to the loss of water. No significant exo- or endo-thermic phenomena are evident. The presence of Pt (Fig. 1(d)) does not lead to any relevant modification to the TG/DTA profile, indicating that the decomposition of Co nitrate is not significantly affected by the presence of the noble metal. The results obtained with the samples prepared starting from Co-acetate (2.4CoAc,4.8CoAc and 4.8CoAc/Pt) are shown in Fig. 1(b, c, e). The TG/DTA profile of the 2.4CoAc sample (Fig. 1(b)) shows a weight loss (near 2%) in the 50–120 °C T-range due to the loss of water. Then, the DTA curve shows a sharp peak with a maximum at 264 °C indicating a very fast and exothermic reaction (weight loss of ≈ 8.5%) associated to the oxidation of the acetate species. This is in line with previous findings [15]. By increasing the Co-loading (4.8CoAc in Fig. 1(c)), the DTA curve significantly changes with the onset at 218 °C of two well-defined peaks with maxima at 258 and 274 °C (Fig. 1(c)), respectively. This suggests that doubling the fuel charge, the decomposition of the acetate no longer takes place through a one fast single step (as shown in Fig. 1(b)) but it occurs through the formation of an intermediate compound. This is in line with previous findings assessing that the acetate decomposition goes through the formation of Co4(CH3CO2)6O species prior to decompose into Co-oxides [39]. Finally, the TG/DTA profile of the 4.8CoAc/Pt sample (Fig. 1(e)) is similar to that of the corresponding Pt-free sample (Fig. 1(c)). Indeed, the oxidative decomposition of cobalt acetate in air results in a weight loss linked to two significant exothermic phenomena. However, these phenomena are more intense and shifted to slightly lower temperatures (≈ 15-20 °C), thus suggesting a catalyzing effect of Pt in the decomposition of the Co-acetate precursor. The ability of Pt in lowering the activation barrier of the decomposition of organic components was reported by Du et al. [40]. In order to gain more insights into the species formed during the Co-nitrate and Co-acetate decomposition, O2-TPSR experiments are also carried out on the 4.8CoNit and 2.4CoAc samples, and results are shown in Fig. 2 . In the case of the 4.8CoNit sample (Fig. 2(a)), the H2O signal increases from 30 °C until a maximum at 89 °C indicating the dehydration of the sample. This is in line with the TG/DTA measurements shown above. The decomposition of Co nitrate into Co oxides species starts from ≈150 °C and it is linked to NO evolution, with a maximum at 178 °C, in line with the occurrence of the following reaction (1): (1) 3 Co(NO3)2 → Co3O4 + 6 NO + 4 O2 No O2 evolution is evident due to the high oxygen concentration present in the feed gas. In the case of the 2.4CoAc sample (Fig. 2(b)) the H2O signal increases from 30 °C until a maximum reached at 75 °C due to the sample dehydration. Then an increase in the CO2 signal is observed, which increases from 180 °C showing a maximum at 267 °C associated to a significant O2 consumption. A minor amount of CO is also observed. These results indicate that the exothermic peak detected in the DTA curve in Fig. 1(b) is related to the acetate combustion, which leads to the release of carbon dioxide and water [11–23] (reaction (2)): (2) 3Co(CH3COO)2 + 12.5 O2 → Co3O4 + 12 CO2 + 9 H2O 3.1.2 Morphological and structural properties of the calcined catalysts The actual Co loading of the stabilized alumina and of the catalysts obtained by ICP-MS analyses is in line with the target value (Table 1 ). This is relevant especially for the Co-acetate catalysts, because it indicates that the exothermic phenomena occurring during calcination do not cause any loss of cobalt, (i.e. through the formation of volatile cobalt-carbonyl compounds, like Co2(CO)8 species [41]). Also, the Pt content on the CoNit/Pt/Al2O3 (s) and CoAc/Pt/Al2O3 (s) catalysts is in line with the theoretical value. The BET area (SBET) and pore volume (Vp) of all the calcined catalysts are lower than those related to the corresponding Al2O3 (s) support (Table 1) due to the Co-addition and the thermal treatments carried out over the samples after the Co-impregnation step. All catalysts display non-reversible adsorption–desorption isotherms with a hysteresis loop characteristic of capillary condensation in mesopores (dp = 2-50 nm). The isotherms of the catalysts (not shown) reach a plateau above a certain relative pressure, indicating that most of the pores in these solids fall within the mesopore range. The relative pressure at which the plateau is attained slightly increases from P/P0 = 0.94 for both CoNit/Al2O3 (s) and CoNit/Pt/Al2O3 (s) samples to 0.97 for both the unpromoted Co-acetate catalysts and to 0.98 for the CoAc/Pt/Al2O3 (s) catalyst, respectively. This may reflect a modest increase in the mean size of the mesopores [42]. The pore size distributions (PSD) in the 2-50 nm range obtained from the absorption branch of the N2 isotherm using the BJH method [43] is shown in Fig. 3 (b). According to N2 physisorption isotherms, the PSD of the catalysts display a unimodal trend centered on 12 nm for both the Co-nitrate catalysts and on 15-16 nm for the Co-acetate catalysts. Notably, while the PSD of the Co-nitrate catalysts is similar to that obtained with the starting Al2O3 (s) support (Fig. 3(b)), that related to the samples prepared with Co-acetate as Co-precursor are shifted to bigger values. The different PSD of the Co-acetate catalysts may be related to the strong exothermic phenomena occurring during the catalyst calcination, which producing a large expansion of the gases may cause an enlargement of pores, due to distortion of the alumina lamellae. We believe that this effect is intensified by the fact that the calcination step was not adequately monitored (i.e. without monitoring the air space velocity) [44]. This effect is even more pronounced in the presence of Pt that acts as catalyst in the oxidation of Co-acetate (Fig. 1 (e)). The diffraction patterns of all the calcined catalysts are shown in Fig. 4 . The pattern of the Al2O3 (s) support is also shown for comparison purposes. All the samples are characterized by crystalline phases associated with Co3O4, CoAl2O4 and γ-Al2O3. No peaks representative of the CoO phase are detected in the calcined samples, thus indicating that both the Co-nitrate and Co-acetate species decompose into Co tetroxide species during calcination. The average Co3O4 crystallites size calculated for CoAc/Al2O3 (s) and CoAc/Pt/Al2O3 (s) catalysts is 26 and 28 nm, respectively. These values are even bigger than those measured on the Co-nitrate samples, showing values near 20 nm. Notably, the Co3O4 crystallites of both the Co-acetate and Co-nitrate catalysts is even bigger than the pore diameter of the initial support material, indicating the migration of the cobalt particles to the outside of the pores [44]. The average Co3O4 size calculated for the CoAc VIII/Al2O3 (s) catalyst is, instead, 7 nm, thus indicating a strong effect of the number of calcinations adopted during the catalyst preparation on the final Co3O4 dispersion. We recall that this sample is prepared calcining the sample after each Co-impregnation step, which means that the number of calcinations doubles with respect to the CoAc/Al2O3 (s) sample. These results may be related to the onset of sintering phenomena occurring during the two consecutive impregnations. In particular, we believe that the impregnated Co-acetate species coalesce and aggregate with the previously loaded cobalt-acetate species, thus resulting in the formation of bigger cobalt particles during calcination. Another explanation may be related to the differences observed during the acetate decomposition (Fig. 1), which becomes slower due to the formation of the intermediate tetracobalt hexaacetate oxides by increasing the Co-loading (i.e. the fuel charge). This, in turn, risks to promote the mobility of the precursor during calcination thus resulting in a worsening of the cobalt dispersion. Notably, the addition of Pt into the formulation of the Co-acetate catalyst results in a slight increase of the average Co3O4 crystallites size (i.e. from 26 nm of CoAc/Al2O3 (s) sample to 28 nm of CoAc/Pt/Al2O3 (s) catalyst). This is reasonably related to the catalyzing effect of Pt observed during the decomposition of the Co-acetate precursor (Fig. 1(e)). 3.1.3 Features of the reduced catalysts The H2-TPR profiles of the calcined CoNit/Al2O3 (s) and CoAc/Al2O3 (s) catalysts are compared in Fig. 5 . The CoNit/Al2O3 (s) sample shows two main reduction peaks with maxima at 385 and 622 °C, associated to the reduction of Co3O4 to CoO and of CoO to metallic Co, respectively [5,35]. The small peak at 276 °C is associated to the reduction of residual cobalt nitrates species present after calcination. A broader peak can be detected at T ≥ 800 °C, which corresponds to the reduction of Cox+ species highly interacting with the support. These species are those related to the Co-aluminates species present on the alumina support, as in fact indicated by the TPR profile of the Al2O3 (s) support shown in our previous studies [5,35]. At variance, the calcined CoAc/Al2O3 (s) catalyst has a single reduction peak with the maximum at 413 °C and two high-temperature shoulders at 545 and 700 °C (Fig. 5). The first peak at 413 °C is possibly related to the reduction of the Co3O4 species into CoO, while the shoulders are both believed to correspond to the reduction of CoO particles into Co° with different size. Also in this case, the onset of the last reduction peak at T > 800 °C is mainly related to the reduction of the stabilizing CoAl2O4 species. Accordingly, the main difference between the H2-TPR profiles of the Co-acetate and Co-nitrate catalysts is that the two cobalt reduction steps (from Co3O4 to CoO and from CoO to Co0) are well distinguishable on the Co-nitrate catalyst, while are partially superimposed on the Co-acetate sample. Such a difference is reasonably related to the size of the starting Co oxide particles. In this regard, there are clear indications that the reduction of the Co3O4 species into CoO is almost unaffected by the crystalline size of the starting Co3O4, while the reduction of the CoO particles into Co0 is strongly particle size-dependent [5,35]. In particular, it was reported that the reduction of CoO is shifted to lower temperatures by increasing the particles size [5,35]. It is therefore speculated that the bigger Co3O4 particles present in the case of the CoAc/Al2O3 (s) catalyst with respect to CoNit/Al2O3 (s) lead to the formation of larger CoO particles. These species, in turn, are more easily reducible, thus leading to the partial overlapping of the reduction peaks in the TPR profiles of the CoAc/Al2O3 (s) sample. This is indeed well supported by the H2-TPR profile of the CoAc VIII/Al2O3 (s) catalyst having 7 nm as starting average Co3O4 crystallites size, where the two cobalt reduction peaks (Co3+→Co2+ and Co2+→Co0, respectively) are again clearly distinguishable (Fig. 5). The reducibility of the CoAc/Al2O3 (s), CoNit/Al2O3 (s) and CoAc VIII/Al2O3 (s) catalysts is investigated by running H2-TPR analysis on the samples after in-situ reduction at 400 °C for 17 h under a flow of pure H2, and results are shown in Fig. 6 (a, b, c). Based on previous in-situ X-ray measurements [5,35], we can safely assume the absence of Co3O4 species on the sample reduced in H2 at 400 °C, and thus the H2 consumption in the TPR analysis of the reduced catalyst corresponds to the amount of CoO present on the sample (Fig. 6). The fraction of Co oxides particles reduced after the H2-treatment at 400 °C (indicated as xCo° in Table 1), determined by the difference between the H2 consumption measured in the TPR analysis of the calcined and reduced samples respectively, is graphically shown by the areas highlighted in Fig. 6. As shown in Fig. 6(a), the peak assigned to the Co3+→Co2+ reduction disappears in the reduced CoNit/Al2O3 (s) sample, indicating that residual Co3O4 species are not present after our activation conditions. On the contrary, the CoO to Co° reduction peak is still partially present, indicating an incomplete reduction of this sample. Accordingly, the fraction of Co metal species (xCo°, Table 1) present on the reduced CoNit/Al2O3 (s) catalyst is around 39%. Also in the case of the CoAc/Al2O3 and CoAc VIII/Al2O3 (s) catalysts (Fig. 6(b, c)), the peak assigned to the Co3+→Co2+ reduction disappears, regardless of the starting Co3O4 crystallites size, while the peaks assigned to the reduction of the CoO species are still present. The fraction of Co metal species calculated for the CoAc/Al2O3 (s) sample is 52% (xCo°, Table 1), while that one estimated for the CoAc VIII/Al2O3 (s) sample is 9.3%, thus confirming that small Co-oxides particles are more difficult to be reduced at the same reduction conditions. The peaks observed at high temperature associated with the reduction of Co-aluminates match closely with those observed in the TPR profile of the corresponding calcined CoNit/Al2O3 (s), CoAc/Al2O3 (s) and CoAc VIII/Al2O3 (s) catalysts. This indicates that the cobalt species used as stabilizing agent “survive” the 17 h reduction in H2 at 400 °C. This is in line with the difficult reduction of the Al2O3 (s) support at the typical catalyst activation conditions [5,35]. The H2-TPR profiles of the Pt-promoted calcined CoNit/Pt/Al2O3 (s) and CoAc/Pt/Al2O3 (s) catalysts are shown in Fig. 6(d, e). In the case of the CoNit/Pt/Al2O3 (s) catalyst, the two major reduction peaks occur at lower temperature with respect to the corresponding Pt-free sample. In particular, the maximum of the Co3O4 to CoO and CoO to Co° reduction peaks occurs at 326 and 522 °C, respectively. This is in line with the well-known effect of Pt in lowering the cobalt reduction temperatures [35,45]. The H2-TPR profile of the CoAc/Pt/Al2O3 (s) sample (Fig. 6(e)) is characterized by one main single peak at 405 °C with a hardly detectable small shoulder at 250 °C. This peak can be attributed to the reduction of the Co3O4 species into Co°. In this case, the intermediate formation of CoO species from Co3O4 is even more hardly detectable than in the CoAc/Al2O3 (s) sample (i.e. shoulders at 545 and 700 °C in Fig. 6(b)), due to the fact that in the presence of Pt the cobalt reduction becomes very fast and effective. After in-situ reduction at 400 °C for 17 h in pure H2, the Co3+ → Co° reduction peak completely disappears on the H2-TPR profile of both the CoNit/Pt/Al2O3 (s) and CoAc/Pt/Al2O3 (s) catalysts (red traces in Fig. 6(d, e)). This means that both the catalysts are completely reduced after the H2-treatment at 400 °C (xCo°≈ 100%, Table 1). Finally, H2-chemisorption experiments were performed. As shown in Table 1, the total amount of hydrogen adsorbed on CoAc/Al2O3 (s) catalyst, representative of the number of metallic Co sites, is similar to that measured on the CoNit/Al2O3 (s) sample (4.0∙10-5 vs 3.9∙10-5 molH2/gcat, Table 1). This depends on the fact that the higher degree of reduction of CoAc/Al2O3 (s) catalyst with respect to CoNit/Al2O3 (s) sample compensates for the larger Co° crystallites. As a result, the number of active sites is similar for the two catalysts. In line with the results of the TPR, the Co° dispersion (D, Table 1) calculated by taking into account the reducibility of the samples is 4.6% for CoAc/Al2O3 (s) and 6.3% for CoNit/Al2O3 (s), confirming that Co° clusters are bigger on the Co-acetate samples (dCo° = 21 vs 15 nm, Table 1). The total amount of hydrogen adsorbed on CoAc VIII/Al2O3 (s) catalyst is lower than those determined on the reduced CoAc/Al2O3 (s) and CoNit/Al2O3 (s) samples (2.8∙10-5 molH2/gcat), in line with the significantly lower catalyst reducibility. The resulting Co° dispersion is 19.2 % corresponding to an average Co° size of 5 nm. The amount of hydrogen adsorbed during H2-chemisorption on CoAc/Pt/Al2O3 (s) catalyst is 60%, which is higher than that found on the corresponding unpromoted samples (6.4∙10-5 vs 3.9∙10-5 molH2/gcat, Table 1). However, considering the full reduction of this sample, the Co° dispersion is as low as 4.0 %. This corresponds to average Co metal particles size of 24 nm (Table 1).Notably, it is characterized by the highest average dimension of Co0 particles among all the catalysts. Different results are obtained on the CoNit/Pt/Al2O3 (s) sample. In this case, the amount of hydrogen adsorbed during H2 chemisorption is 4.5 times higher than that found on the corresponding unpromoted samples (1.8∙10-4 vs 4.0∙10-5 molH2/gcat, Table 1). This result cannot be explained only with the higher amount of Co metal species present on the Pt-promoted sample: the increased in the reducibility (39% for the unpromoted sample, 100% for the sample with Pt) can only justify an increase of 2.6 times. The high chemisorption capability suggests instead an increased dispersion of Co° crystallites (12 %, corresponding to an average Co metal particle size of 8 nm) with respect to that of Co3O4 clusters (6.3%, corresponding to an average Co metal particles size of 15 nm, Table 1). Notably, the presence of a large fraction of small Co° particles in the CoNit/Pt/Al2O3 (s) sample is also supported by the in-situ magnetic measurements analyses reported in [35]. 3.2 Catalytic performance 3.2.1 Catalytic performance of CoNit/Al2O3 (s), CoAc/Al2O3 (s) and CoAc VIII/Al2O3 (s) The steady-state results expressed in terms of CO conversion obtained at 210 °C with the unpromoted CoNit/Al2O3 (s), CoAc/Al2O3 (s) and CoAc VIII/Al2O3 (s) catalysts are compared in Fig. 7 . The selectivity to CH4, C2-C4 hydrocarbons, olefins and paraffins in the C2-C17 range, C25+ hydrocarbons and the C25+ yield are also shown. The CoAc/Al2O3 (s) shows higher activity, expressed in terms of CO conversion (22.7% vs. 8.5%) than the CoAc VIII/Al2O3 (s) catalyst. It also shows halved selectivity to CH4 (SCH4 = 9.3% vs. 18.5%) and lower selectivity to short-chain hydrocarbons (SC2-C4 = 10.2% vs. 13.8%). The CoAc/Al2O3 (s) catalyst has higher selectivity to unsaturated hydrocarbons in the C2-C17 range ( S o l ( C 2 - C 17 ) ≈ 15.6% vs. 9.0%) and lower selectivity to the corresponding C2-C17 paraffins ( S p a r ( C 2 - C 17 ) ≈ 32.9% vs. 51.9%), which results in a higher olefin to paraffin ratio (O/P) distribution (Fig. 8 (a)) with respect to the CoAc VIII/Al2O3 (s) catalyst. The CoAc/Al2O3 (s) catalyst outperforms the CoAc VIII/Al2O3 (s) sample in terms of C25+ selectivity (SC25+). Indeed, the SC25+ is 23.6% and 6.3% for CoAc/Al2O3 (s) and CoAc VIII/Al2O3 (s) catalysts, respectively. The higher selectivity to long-chain hydrocarbons is also well evident in the Anderson-Schulz-Flory (ASF) plots shown in Fig. 8(b). The ASF plots show the typical positive and negative deviations for methane and C2 hydrocarbons, respectively, and a change of slope for a carbon number around 8. The chain growth probability, estimated by considering the hydrocarbons with more than 15 carbon atoms (αC15+), follows the same order of the selectivity to C25+: CoAc/Al2O3 (s) ( α C 15 + ≈0.906) > CoAc VIII/Al2O3 (s) ( α C 15 + ≈0.843). The results obtained in terms of CO conversion rate can be explained with the fact that the CoAc VIII/Al2O3 (s) sample has a lower number of Co° sites (i.e. lower amount of hydrogen adsorbed during H2-chemisorption: 2.8∙10-5 vs 4.0∙10-5 molH2/gcat) than the CoAc/Al2O3 (s) catalyst. Furthermore, its Co° centers are also intrinsically less active, since they fall in that TOF-size range where the turnover frequency of the active sites quickly decreases even more than one order of magnitude upon varying the average crystallite size by a few nanometers (Fig. 9 ) [6,9,35,46–48]. The small size of the Co0 sites of the CoAc VIII/Al2O3 (s) also affects its selectivity to the main FTS products. Indeed, the results obtained in terms of products distribution are in line with the fact that the hydrogenating ability of the catalyst is enhanced in the presence of very small crystallites, thus boosting methane formation, hindering the chain growth mechanism and enhancing the secondary hydrogenation of olefins to the corresponding paraffins. Concerning the comparison of the reactivity of the Co-acetate and Co-nitrate catalysts calcined the same number of times, the CoNit/Al2O3 (s) catalyst outperforms the CoAc/Al2O3 (s) catalyst in terms of CO conversion. In contrast, the FT products distribution worsens with the CoNit/Al2O3 (s) sample with a slightly higher selectivity to methane and to short-chain hydrocarbons C2-C4 together with a lower selectivity to high molecular weight hydrocarbons (SC25+). Again, Figs. 8 and 9 clearly reflect the results obtained in terms of selectivity to the main FTS products. Co-nitrate has lower O/P ratio, due to the combined effect of the lower olefins selectivity linked to a higher paraffins selectivity in the same C2-C17 range, and it has lower αC15+ of 0.894 than the CoAc/Al2O3 (s) catalyst. In this case, the higher CO conversion of the catalyst prepared using Co-nitrate as Co-precursor with respect to the Co-acetate cannot be explained on the basis of the H2-chemisorption results, since the samples have similar number of Co° sites (i.e. similar amount of hydrogen adsorbed during H2-chemisorption). We believe that the higher activity can be explained on the basis of the different Co° particles size of the catalysts [6]: the average Co° particles size of the Co-acetate catalyst is, indeed, about 1.5 times larger than that of the Co-nitrate. In this regard, there is a general consensus on the fact that the activation for the dissociation of hydrogen is favored over that of carbon monoxide on small Co° crystallites, leading to higher hydrogen to carbon ratio on the catalyst surface [10]. This in turn boosts the kinetics of the FTS, i.e. the CO conversion rate. Similarly, the FT products distribution is strictly linked to the Co0 particles size. In this regard, the catalytic surface of the CoAc/Al2O3 (s) catalyst is characterized by bigger Co0 clusters, thus resulting in a less hydrogenating ability of the catalyst (i.e. lower CH4 selectivity with the inverse trend for the C5+ selectivity) if compared to the CoNit/Al2O3 (s) sample. Again, this is also particularly evident from the O/P ratio plot obtained with these catalysts, which increases by increasing the average Co0 particles size. The C25+ yield of CoAc/Al2O3 (s) and CoNit/Al2O3 (s) catalyst is similar (5.4 and 5.8 %, respectively) thus indicating that the worsening of the catalyst activity, expressed in terms of CO conversion rate, when Co-acetate is used as Co-precursor, is balanced by the improvement observed in terms of C25+ selectivity (Fig. 7). 3.2.2 Catalytic performance of CoAc/Pt/Al2O3 (s) and CoNit/Pt/Al2O3 (s) The steady-state results expressed in terms of CO conversion with the Pt-promoted CoAc/Pt/Al2O3 (s) and CoNit/Pt/Al2O3 (s) catalysts are compared in Fig. 10 . The selectivities to CH4, C2-C4 hydrocarbons, olefins and paraffins in the C2-C17 range, C25+ hydrocarbons and the C25+ yield are also shown. The CoNit/Pt/Al2O3 (s) catalyst outperforms CoAc/Pt/Al2O3 (s). This is in line with: (i) the increase of the number of Co° surface sites available for the reaction, as determined by H2-chemisorption (see Table 1) and (ii) the expected higher H/C ratio on the surface, which is boosted by the smaller Co° crystallites of the CoNit/Pt/Al2O3 (s) sample. The results obtained in terms of FT products distribution reflect those obtained with the corresponding unpromoted samples. Briefly, the selectivity to CH4 (SCH4), as well as the selectivity to short-chain hydrocarbons (SC2-C4), of the CoAc/Pt/Al2O3 (s) catalyst is lower than that measured with the CoNit/Pt/Al2O3 (s) sample (Fig. 9). The CoAc/Pt/Al2O3 (s) catalyst has higher selectivity to unsaturated hydrocarbons in the C2-C17 range and lower selectivity to the corresponding C2-C17 paraffins than CoNit/Pt/Al2O3 (s) (Fig. 9), thus resulting in a higher O/P ratio (Fig. 11 (a)). The CoAc/Pt/Al2O3 (s) catalyst also shows a higher C25+ selectivity (SC25+), as well as a higher chain growth probability (Fig. 11(b)). As a result, in terms of C25+ yield, the CoNit/Pt/Al2O3 (s) outperforms CoAc/Pt/Al2O3 (s) (Fig. 10). This means that the much higher activity, expressed in terms of CO conversion, prevails on its lower C25+ selectivity. Again, these results can be explained considering the higher H coverage on the active sites of the CoNit/Pt/Al2O3 (s), which has smaller Co0 crystallites than the CoAc/Pt/Al2O3 (s) catalyst. Notably, the reactivity of the CoAc/Pt/Al2O3 (s) catalyst is similar to that obtained with the CoAc/Al2O3 (s) sample even though the H2 uptake increases in the Pt-promoted catalyst (Table 1). This result suggests that the size of the Co metal particles, which also affects the hydrogen to carbon ratio on the catalyst surface during the reaction [10], influences the catalyst reactivity to a larger extent than the number of Co metal sites available for the reaction. 3.2.3 Catalyst stability As shown in Table 2 , all the catalysts were tested under industrially relevant operating conditions for at least 70 h, unusual for lab-scale catalyst activity, showing stability with time on stream (T.o.S.) both in terms of activity and selectivity. This is probably related to the support stabilization with Co-aluminates species, which prevent any interaction between the active Co° centers and the γ-Al2O3 support during FTS. 4 Conclusions In this study the effect of the Co-precursors on the main features of Co-based FT catalysts is investigated. It is found that using Co(CH3COO)2∙4H2O as Co-precursor leads to an exothermic decomposition of the precursor into Co oxides during the calcination step. The rate of the decomposition depends on the amount of cobalt-acetate species present on the sample after impregnation. Indeed, by doubling the Co-loading from 2.4 (one step of impregnation, CoAc VIII/Al2O3 (s)) to 4.8 wt.% (two consecutive impregnation steps, CoAc/Al2O3 (s)), the decomposition rate slows down going through the formation of an intermediate compound. This, in turn, negatively affects the final Co3O4 dispersion of the catalyst, with the presence of big Co3O4 particles over the support, which are even bigger than those formed from Co-nitrate (CoNit/Al2O3 (s)). The reducibility of the catalysts follows the same trend of the size of the Co3O4 crystallites: CoAc/Al2O3 (s) > CoNit/Al2O3 (s) > CoAc VIII/Al2O3 (s). When tested in the FTS, CoAc VIII/Al2O3 (s) shows lower CO conversion than CoAc/Al2O3 (s), in line with the lower amount of Co metal sites available at the catalytic surface and its lower TOF. The results obtained in terms of products distribution are a clear effect of the Co0 particles size. The latter also explains the different catalytic performances of the CoAc/Al2O3 (s)and CoNit/Al2O3 (s) catalyst. The addition of Pt into the formulation of the Co-acetate catalyst catalyzes the decomposition of the Co-acetate species into Co-oxides during calcination, thus resulting in a slight increase of the average Co3O4 crystallites size. On the contrary, Pt has no effect during the Co-nitrate decomposition. In line with well-known ability of Pt in favoring the reduction of the Co3O4 particles into Co0 species, both CoNit/Pt/Al2O3 (s) and CoAc/Pt/Al2O3 (s) reach the full degree of reduction at the adopted activation conditions. Concerning the catalytic performances in the FTS, CoNit/Pt/Al2O3 (s) catalyst outperforms CoAc/Pt/Al2O3 (s) in terms of CO conversion rate in line with the higher number of Co0 surface sites available for the reaction and the expected higher H/C ratio on the surface, which is boosted by its smaller Co0 crystallites. This latter explanation is also in line with the observed effects on the product distribution, showing a minor decrease of the chain growth probability in the case of the CoNit/Pt/Al2O3 (s). However, the increase in the CO conversion overcompensates for the decrease in the C25+ selectivity, thus boosting the C25+ yields. coredata.dc:description: This study investigates the effect of the cobalt precursor (nitrate and acetate) on the catalytic performance in the Fischer-Tropsch synthesis of catalysts supported on stabilized CoAl2O4/Al2O3 pellets. The catalysts are prepared via multi-steps of impregnation of the support with aqueous solutions of cobalt nitrate or acetate followed by calcination in air. The dispersion of the Co3O4 particles obtained via exothermic decomposition of acetate increases if each impregnation is followed by calcination. In fact, halving the calcinations leads to Co3O4 particles even bigger than those formed from cobalt-nitrate. A worsening of the catalytic performances is observed when the Co-acetate catalysts are tested in the FTS. Such a result is explained on the basis of Co0 particles size effect. Pt improves the catalysts reducibility regardless of the Co-precursor. The metallic surface area of the Pt-promoted Co-nitrate catalyst is higher than that of the corresponding Co-acetate catalyst, thus resulting in improved catalytic performances.
coredata.dc:title: Effect of the cobalt-precursor on the reactivity of cobalt-based Fischer-Tropsch catalysts supported on stabilized alumina
